content.description:
Start with some easy stemming to get to the first bolt. Make a few reachy moves through horizontals to gain the shallow corner. Fire the crux, then pull onto the slab and blunt arete above for an easy, enjoyable romp to the anchor. The lower part seeps sometimes, but the holds that are generally wet are big, so it is worth a go.

The overhanging nature of this route mostly protects the belayer, but since this is a new route, be aware there is a higher than average chance for loose rock. Wear a helmet.
content.protection: 7 bolts to rap ring anchor.
content.location: Climbs the black streak 15' right of the large corner where Drive-By Shooting and Balcony Route start.

content.description: Begin in the wide crack and climb up to the face. Pro is good on the face, and good foot and hand jams. Climb to the easy section above which has some loose rock. Have someone follow and walk off. Gear anchor is best probably 10 feet past the flat section.
content.protection: Standard rack.
content.location:
Head past the

Moai Crack

west. The route is after

In Spite of Ourselves

, but before reaching the Baby Bear Buttress. Look for a right facing corner on a small, semi-detached buttress.

content.description:
Fairly standard Madison river climbing. Interesting features, but nothing to write home about. Left of two routes up here.

Message me if you know route name/FA.
content.protection:
It seems there are several ways to start this route.

1) Build a bomber anchor using #1, 2, and 3 BD cams, as the route starts by moving up and right over about 60' of exposure. Climb 15' to the obvious first bolt. From here trend left for about 20' of runout (you may be able to squeak a cam in somewhere in here) to the next bolt. From here the bolts are spaced normally. 7 bolts to chains.

2) Skip the first obvious bolt, and use the mediocre crack to place some small gear up to the first bolt ~30' up. Finish on bolts to chains.
content.location: Hike up the gulley about 30m left of Jack Attack. At the apex, scramble up and right onto a large ledge. There are two mixed/sport routes up here.

content.description:
Crux is pulling the roof.

Message me if you know route name/FA.
content.protection: 6 bolts to hangers with descent biners on them. Could use some chains.
content.location: Head up into the gulley about 30m left of Jack Attack. Route starts right at the apex of the gulley. Obvious bolt line going up over a small roof.

content.description: Clip the first bolt and work right to the jugs at the second bolt. After clipping the second bolt, make the first crux move and enjoy a nice rest at the third bolt. From here, move up to the fourth and fifth bolts via a crimp ladder and decide which second crux you want to tackle. Either head straight up to the anchor, or traverse left along the roof (easier, but more moves).
content.protection: 5 bolts to rap rings.
content.location: Look for The Kingdom (tallest line in the area) and this is the bolted route just to the right of it. This will be the first route that you come to after passing through the narrowest section of the approach gully.

content.description:
P1: Climb the runout seam just right of Substandard for ~30', then angle right. Two bolts below the roof. Chains on large ledge. Probably best toproped. Fun pitch!

P2: 5.9: Climb to the first bolt, and then move to the right on gear the rest of the way to chains.

P2 (alternate) 5.11a: Climb the bolted line directly above the belay.

Bolts and chains are reportedly 25 years old. I thought they seemed ok.
content.protection:
P1: Few small cams and 2 draws (1 extendable for the first bolt is good). Gear is extremely sparse below the first bolts. Chain anchors.

P2 5.9: Draws and a small rack of cams and stoppers is good. 5.11a: Draws. Chain anchors.

content.description:
P1: Climb theÂ crack into the left facing dihedral. Some easier terrain brings you to the large belay ledge with chains. (5.7)

P2: Move left and up into the harder to protect upper crack system with some slopey face holds. Follow this to chains. (5.8)

Can be done as 1 long pitch.
content.protection: Single set of cams to BD#2 and some nuts should do it. Chain anchors.
content.location: First route on the right side of the huge gaping chimney.

content.description: The name says it all. Tons of slopers.
content.protection: 4 bolts to chains and room for one small cam to protect first few moves to first bolt. Or stick clip the first bolt and skip the cam.

content.description: This route was really hard for me but extremely enjoyable for the two people that I know that have climbed it that onsight the grade. Theres a lower crux and another right before the chains.
content.protection: 10-12 bolts to chain anchor.
content.location: Find the Baby Bear buttress about the middle of the Winter Wall and walk left up a hidden gully to an elevated belay. One belay bolt can be found here. Climb the micro tower then up the face. This is the right of the two routes here.

content.description: Short, stout, slightly overhanging route. East facing, thus shaded after noon.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chains.
content.location: Upper left side of Winter Wall - Left

climbs.name: The Noses Right Off Our Faces

content.description: Short but sweet hand crack that starts under the large roof and escapes right. Bottom third is a bit scruffy, followed by about 15 feet of vertical hand crack. Turn the lip and the last third is low 5th class to the chains. An unknown route given this name in the more recent Vassilopoulos guide.
content.protection: A few hand sized pieces
content.location: Crack right of the stout roof crack across from the pull out

content.description: Balancey and smeary. Not a lot of huge jugs. Lots of slopers and side pulls.
content.protection: 6 bolts to chains.

content.description: Crack starts wide (crux) and narrows up top. Arete has some good holds to offer. After the crack ends, easy ledgy terrain to the chains. If climbed direct, it is runout, but if you step right there are some placements to be had, albeit with some long slings.
content.protection: Single rack of cams to 3" and small stoppers. Chains up top (shared with two routes on river facing side of formation).
content.location: Left side of the huge gaping chimney. Just around to the right of the arete from The Noses Right Off Our Faces.

content.description: As with other climbs in this area, slopey holds galore.
content.protection: Bolts to chains.

content.description: The direct start goes up the ramp with the thin crack that trends right and is the most difficult option. You also have the choice of unprotected (10ft, but easy) face climbing on the right side of the crack. The last option is to skip this completely and traverse in from the right on the ledge. Once established on the ledge, follow the intermittent cracks on the left side of the arete to the top. Stay close to the arete as you head up and go to the right side of the arete once to navigate a bulge. Shortly after the bulge, enjoy some really sweet pockets as you continue to feel more and more exposed.
content.protection:
Gear from .1 - 2. #3 and #4 optional.

Bolted anchor at top with rap rings.
content.location: Look for the obvious ramp that trends right. This is right where the gully that you hike in from narrows.

content.description:
Look for the chains atop the first pitch. 60 meter rope is adequate.

p1 Begin in a small corner and climb a short handcrack to easier climbing and chains up and right

p2 Climb up and mostly traverse right about 20 feet to a sloping ledge. Climb a up a crack 5.9 (crux move) to a runout groove like formation to a nice ledge with chains.

p3 Great pitch. Climb the corner up to a roof with chains above the roof.
content.protection: Bring some long runners for the second pitch traverse. Gear to 4 inches.
content.location: Rappel from chains. From the top of pitch two rappel straight down to independant rap anchors.

content.description: Climb 30' up to a large roof. Climb the hand crack directly through the roof (crux) to easier ground above. Continue up until you reach the anchors.
content.protection: Standard rack. Chain anchors at top.
content.location: Just to the left of the big chimney, directly across from the pull out. Look for the big roof, and that's your climb. Single rope rappel to get down.

content.description:
Stick clip recommended. Start just left of a long horizontal sloper rail on edges. Launch into a tough boulder problem on small crimps and ambiguous holds with good feet. Move up and right to gain some cool jug rail features. Get a rest, do a few more hard moves, then climb easier, but pumpy terrain to the anchors.

An alternate, easier start: Traverse leftward to the second bolt (rest jug) from higher up the gully. This skips the crux, brings the climb down to ~5.10+, and is still safe.

Since this is a new route, be aware there is a higher than average chance for loose rock. Wear a helmet.
content.protection: 5 bolts to ring anchors.
content.location: Midway up the gully on the far right side of Winter Wall. Look for the line of bolts just before reaching the shallow left facing corner that marks the start of The Kingdom.

content.description:
Slightly easier variation to GSW. Face climb past two bolts, then move into the cruiser finger crack. One more bolt above the crack, then move right and finish up on shared bolts with GSW.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection:
6 draws (1 extendable for above crack)

A few finger sized cams and nuts

Shiny new chain anchor
content.location:
Leftmost route on this wall.

This wall is directly above the small pullout next to the river, 100' to the right of the "Main area"

content.description:
Great steep hand crack down low, characteristic Winter Wall area slopers up top. More sustained down low than the left variation.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection:
A few hand sized cams (0.75 - 2).

4 draws (1 extendable)

Shiny new chain anchor.
content.location: This route is on the wall directly above the small pullout next to the river, 150' to the right of the "Main Area". Scramble up the scree field directly below wall to get to the base.

content.description: When GP and CS de-grit, they might compete for the best sport lines of the grade in the area. A great warm up on positive, incut edges.
content.protection: 9 bolts to chain anchor.
content.location: The right route of the two routes on Riot Rock (the pyramidal shaped rock on the far left side of the area).

climbs.name: Get A Whiff Of These Hands

content.description:
Hop in the flaring "chimney" 20ft downslope from Baby Bear 5.8, Â take the handcrack to the top.

Gear anchor for 2nd, easy walkoff.

Climb was fun, was not in guidebook or MP give it a go!
content.protection: Standard rack.

climbs.name: Drive-By Shooting
climbs.fa: Tom Kalakay, Betty Kalakay, Skyler Pauli (April 2007)

content.description: This mostly bolted route follows the large corner uphill and right of the GSW routes. Pull the large roof by traversing left on awesome holds, then continue up the dihedral above. If you are comfortable with runout easy climbing, there is no need for gear. Otherwise, bring something in the finger to thin hands range.
content.protection: Bolts, with a few small cams for the upper corner. Rap anchors.
content.location: Starts off a small bench uphill and right of GSW. It is the left line of bolts.

content.description: Super fun, positive edge climbing.
content.protection: 11 bolts to chain anchor.
content.location: The Riot Rock is the left most buttress on the Winter Wall. It is pyramidal in shape with room for more routes.

content.description:
Start up a right facing corner with a fixed piton in it. Follow the crack system up to a small bush at the base of a left facing corner. Scooch your way up the easy offwidth (#4 protects, watch out for bird poo) with good hands on the arete. Traverse left to chains.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection: Cams from 0.3 to 4", stoppers & a few slings. One fixed piton. Chain anchor.
content.location: About 200 yards left of Main Area. Look for the large horizontal black band of rock about 80' up.

content.description: The right most of the two side-by-side sport lines, this climb gets started with a inobvious crux right off the ground. After the 2nd bolt, the climbing eases, until a reachy move after the roof. There are a couple spots where falling could be bad on this route, so don't get complacent. Although it is entirely bolted, it isn't exactly a sport route in the modern sense.
content.protection: 6 bolts to a rap anchor.
content.location: Far right side of the wall, directly next to Drive-By Shooting.

content.description: A little warm up for the Acid Wall.
content.protection: 5 bolts to chain anchor.
content.location: Baby Bear Buttress is a giant boulder separated from the main wall by about 3 feet. This 3 feet makes up the hidden ramp/gully that brings you to the Acid Wall. Somewhere central Winter Wall.

content.description: Crux down low by first bolt. First moves are kind of exposed over an extra 10 foot drop to your right. Stick clip the first bolt if not totally comfortable at the grade.
content.protection: Bolts to chains. Shares chains with "Slope on a rope".

content.description: This climb scared me until I climbed it. Exiting the dihedral on to the airy face has one of the coolest sequences ever. If its hard, you are missing the thank-god hold.
content.protection: 10 or 12 bolts to chain anchor.
content.location: The Acid Wall is located up a hidden, short and scambly gully about the middle of the Winter Wall. 10 Hits Too Many is the left route, Rumble Strip is the right route. The Baby Bear buttress is the little piece of rock creating the hidden gully.

content.description:
Low angle corner finger crack. What's the opposite of sandbagging? This is it.

Descent:

Rappel route.
content.protection: Light rack of cams/stoppers up to 2". Shares chains with "Noses Right Off Our Faces" and "In Spite of Ourselves".
content.location: Just left of the giant chimney.
